												Lara Croft is searching for an artifact called the Dagger of Xian but discovers that a mysterious organization is also tracking it. If she wants to be the first to reach it and prevent a catastrophic fate for the world, she will need to find the keys that will open the way... elsewhere than in China.I must say that Tomb Raider II isn't perhaps my favorite game in the series, as I'm heavily influenced by the first opus and Anniversary. But the story is well written too. I mean, who doesn't want to follow her under the water or in Italy or in Tibet?The gameplay is pretty much the same as the first game: you jump, you search levers, you move stuff and you shoot anything coming in your way. And Tomb Raider II has a major shift here: instead of the animals or the legendary creatures, your enemies are now humans. Many humans. Many crazy humans. And you're confronted to them more than the animals (true, you have sharks, dogs, even Yetis or spiders). I suppose that maybe, this shift may have contributed to the fact that I'm still clinging more to the first game.But this game is also introducting vehicles for Lara: boat (well in Venice) and the snow bike which I had the most fun with. This is great to take ramps, to jump over pits or to race against the clock. That's also one of the main changes. Another new thing is the fact that you have allies in the game in the form of Tibetan monks. Don't hurt them and they'll let you in peace.Tomb Raider II is also an improvement for Lara herself: she has more weapons (like an harpoon for example) if she needs to defend herself (and trust me, she will need them nearly all the time). But the best improvement is probably aethestic: she's looking more curvy than angular, though she's still wearing her regular outfit.However, during the game, now, Lara changes also clothes. While the change is perhaps minimal, it's more realistic for the levels. It's just a little disappointing that she must find her way on a platform in the middle of the sea, where it's very very industrial. But generally, the landscapes are still sticking to the "Tomb Raider", aka, historical places like the Great Wall of China or Venice but also more mysterious levels like a wreck of a cruiser or a Tibetan monastery. It's very nice done and guess what? The T-Rex makes also a cameo.Anyway, I liked a lot the soundtrack, mainly the one used with the snow bike for the first time.Tomb Raider II is a nice way to keep going with the series. Too bad, it doesn't come with the add-on The Golden Mask (more snowbiking!) but anyway, if you're nostalgic of putting the butler in the fridge, given the price and the regular promotion of -75%/-80%, you shouldn't hesitate.

												Core Design's insanely successful sequel to the original, classic Tomb Raider (1996) is just more of the same. However, for some reason, this statement seems to often be taken as a negative one, whereas I just view it as more of a good thing. And that's exactly what Tomb Raider II is. Much more!Let's start with aesthetics. The graphics are largely improved in comparison with the first game. Lara looks like an even more sexy bunch of polygons this time around, complete with larger and rounder breasts, which I assume took up 60%+ of the development time and budget. Lara also has a ragdoll ponytail, which would actually look quite good, if it didn't look like a three-section staff that could knock somebody out. It would come as no surprise to me if she was almost every teenage guy's wet dream back in '97. Moving on, we have video settings this time around! Yes, actual video settings, and I'm fairly certain the game runs without any emulators or graphical enhancements that weren't there in the original release. There's even support for widescreen resolutions, but I prefer to keep it at 4:3. Textures and other models are largely improved, although for some reason all the male characters look incredibly wrinkly. I think they just started with Winston's model and built upon every male character from there. Finally, there's an improved lighting engine, which also plays a faily big role in the game itself, as well as being a nice visual enhancement. There's only one complaint here, and that's the FMVs. Not only do they have awful scanlines, but the game goes windowed in full-screen and it just looks wrong. However, when you compare that to the first one, where you'd have to alt-tab and the game would sometimes crash, it's not a big deal.Sound-wise, it's not as good as the first, at least in my opinion. The main theme is a gutted remix of the original, but Nathan McRee provides a nice selection of short, dramatic pieces which generally fit each situation well. Lara's new voice actor is good, although for some reason they didn't replace all her lines from the original. Seems a bit odd. All the male voice actors are god awful though. Just awful. Funny, but still awful. Guns sound incredibly satisfying, and there's a larger selection of environmental sounds to add to the atmosphere.In terms of plot, it's very simple; point-A to point-B. Lara hears of a legendary artifact called the Dagger of Xian, visiting China, Italy, and Tibet in the process to claim it. There's a couple of hackneyed villains here and there, but it's all very basic. If you want better stories, I'd player later entires in the series.Nothing much has changed gameplay or control-wise; rather there's just been some additional things slapped onto the already solid gameplay to provide some variety. Levels are insanely long. Like, hours long. There's 17 levels in the game and it took me 24 or so hours to complete. I'm a slow gamer, but that's still insanely long for an action adventure-game. I've also noticed a large increase in difficulty from the first game, and the learning curve is nowhere near as smooth. It seems to be completely random, but all I can say is that I recommend you save after pretty much every puzzle; according to my end statistics, I saved 217 times. There's a lot of instant deaths, and to be honest it feels quite cheap, but I suppose that's why you can save at any time. Secrets have changed and are more rewarding, and completionists will love finding them all. The new weapons are awesome, quite frankly, and some, such as the M16, require some actual tactics to use, rather than just holding control and backflipping.The use of newly added flares takes advantage of the aforementioned improved lighting system, as a lot of areas in the game are too dark to see without them, and it adds a nice extra element of exploration and discovery. Although you can use them underwater, which is kind of funny. Ladders and ziplines are also new, although the former are incredibly cumbersome, overused and slow, and the latter appears about 3 times in the whole game, so they really don't count for much in my book. As such, Lara comes equipped with some new manoeuvres, such as doing a half-turn in mid-air, and the animations for these are all just as fluid and beautiful as in the first game. Lastly, vehicle sections, which I was at first skeptical and hesitant about experiencing, are actually some of the most enjoyable parts of the game. It's a shame then, however, that like ziplines, they appear so rarely throughout the game.So what's the verdict then? Well, Tomb Raider II is everything a perfect sequel should be. It's an improvement over the previous title in an abundance of ways, but at the same time, I think the game suffers a bit from a lack of overall fluidity and pace. For example, my personal favourite parts of the game are the first couple of levels and the last 5, whereas the middle section of the game is all basically indistinguishable, incredibly long and tiring. There's also a lot of backtracking, far more than in the original. This game requires a lot of patience, but I do think it is worth it. The added positives and negatives balance it out to be exactly as good as the original, which I suppose means that it fails a sequel. But that doesn't mean it isn't a kick♥♥♥♥♥ sexy, hi-octane and lengthy adventure.3.5/5

												My 10-year-old self and I can't recommend this game enough. It's classic puzzle-solving at its finest. In fact I'm pretty sure that playing it made me smarter. There's no AI holding your hand here, nor any obnoxious button graphics that flash on-screen and yell at you to mash the Y key to perform some entirely gimmicky and circumstantial roundhouse backflip to the face that you'll never need to do again. Just Lara and her lovably awkward polygons running straight ahead with the arms fully stretched out at a stiff, perpendicular angle to the body. On occasion, you can make her say "No," in a charming British voice, over and over again, and then kill her in a variety of exciting ways. Serously though, the levels are rendered beautifully, leaving just the right amount to the imagination, and many of the puzzles actually require more than three brain cells to figure out. There are no journal entries offering fluff faux "immersion," no toggled map overlays to tell you where you are, and very little clues to help you out - just you and an often convoluted and action-packed pathway from the start of a level to the exit. The levels themselves, especially the memorable Venice series, have personality and often make you feel real suspense and a sense of danger. While some puzzles might frustrate the modern gamer (certain ones depend on very exact placement of Lara to perform a series of jumps with no room for error, for instance, which can get pretty tedious), the feeling of accomplishment you get after finally landing that horrendous jump, or opening that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ door, is so worth the effort. In my opinion, this and the original Tomb Raider are the best installments in the series, mostly thanks to their simplicity. What it lacks in modern graphics, the game makes up for tenfold in gameplay and creativity of story and design. Plus, for the first time, Lara gets to use vehicles, which add a great deal of fun to the levels they appear in, by which I mean you can drive them off cliffs and explode.  All in all, you won't regret giving this a try. Yeah, you'll probably laugh at Lara and make fun of the dated graphics, and swear loudly at the controls, but these days, that's part of the fun. Definitely a must for 90s action/adventure gaming fans and especially people who don't mind video games not insulting their intelligence for a change.Oh and you can lock the butler in the freezer.

My favourite classic Tomb Raider!Why?- Amazing and awesome levels, - VARIOUS levels, - amazing story, - first animated hair and first mobile source of light (flares),- many cool ideas packed into those levels,- very nice FMVs (movie clips with hi-poly models),- many cut-scenes,- amazing music, some those memorable notes which defined TR music,- a big training map (house & garden) available anytime,- an old servant thanks to who Lara was never thirsty (unless frozen :>),- first usable vehicles (boat & snowmobile),- various enemies (human, animals, fantasy creatures) with various weapons,- those moments when the music changed and you discovered new part of the map and you said "WOW!",- those some moments when you was going to s##t your pants (remember those loud howls&roars chasing you in the winter level?),- some nice FANTASY included (the dragon story, the Floating Islands map)...I simply love that part!Level sizes are JUST RIGHT in that part and they found a golden mean between the fight and the exploration!And an important thing many kids forget about. Expensive computers in that era were only capable to play (NOT encode) two MP3 320kbit/s files in realtime and do nothing more. And TR2 creators did such a great 3D game with audio for those computers and overcame those limitations...I believe it was still the moment when great ideas were involved to make the game even more fun!I bought mine game with the TR Collection and I am satisfied.There is a level editor (TRLE) for TR2, available for free! There are many fan-made custom levels for TR2! Those levels are often provided as a full games ready-to-run, but when installing those maps into the Steam game you will get the TR2 music.For Geeks: You can also use the fly-patch as it is compatible with the Steam version and is NOT compatible with the version provided with many custom levels. The fly-patch does NOT mess multiplayer experience as there are no multiplayer in TR2, but this is an unnoficial cheating hack and use it only at your own risk. It may break the gameplay experience and I do not recommend it unless you already did the whole game. You can also find 16:9, 16:10 and 5:4 widescreen support patch. Use only trusted sources and scan patcher files for malware before launching them!TR2 Steam community posted many info about HD textures pack, controller configurations, walkthroughts, etc.BTW: TR2 had the campfire visible in first level... :>DISCLAIMER: If you are 2000+ era, you may not feel like we did in 90s. You may blame a complete lack of mouse support. You may blame tank controls (but Lara does sideways when jumping). You may blame slow movement animations which created that game playable on those computers (we were very happy when having 5FPS in 640x480; well... we played so often using 320x240 back then...). But they are NOT real cons of that game. This is how games were designed back then for those hardware components (mostly no GPU, slow CPU, 4:3 CRT monitor and a ball-mouse). You may miss all those 125 hint arrows per level, glowing items and a voice which is constantly telling you what you should do in that room, but this is why we love those old classics and why we spent a part of our life there without getting bored. Sometimes there is a graphics bug with shadows and you will be forced to live with it, to find a fix or to switch to software renderer (add "-setup" to launch options to invoke the setup window). IMHO if you are still curious and wanna try Classic TRs, buy TR Collection. You will get so many games including: TR1, TR2, TR Anniversary (modern TR1) up to TR2013 with DLCs which has great graphics, cute Lara model and a tiny, but great multiplayer community.

												I strongly believe that a video game can have fantastic atmosphere despite having dated or chunky graphics. With its intricate and creative level design, Tomb Raider II is an excellent example of this, and deserves the attention of any slower-paced adventure gamer today, despite being released almost 20 years ago.The combat isn't very interesting at all, but that's not what I'm here for. When I play the classic Tomb Raider games developed by Core (1-3), I think, "Yay! Oldschool games with a fantastic sense of exploration!", not, "Yay! I get to jump around while shooting a bunch of generic bad guys with awful AI!". Fortunately, there isn't too much combat in TR II, and I often found myself solving puzzles and examining various rooms in complete solitude. Speaking of puzzles, I felt that the game's difficulty was just right -- tricky enough so that I couldn't breeze through a level, but at the same time not ridiculously difficult/illogical as to require a walkthrough whenever a new room is entered. I never felt like there was too much backtracking, either (TR 4 has far too much backtracking in my opinion, and thinking about that game just makes me want to punch something, but I digress).Overall, Tomb Raider II is a very high-quality adventure/exploration game, but I rank it lower than TR 1 or 3 due to the four sunken ship levels that occur about half-way into the game. These levels weren't BAD in design, but I got rather sick of running around rusted and ugly engine rooms after awhile. The other locations were top-notch, though -- Barkhang Monastery is a beautiful place to get lost in. You can expect to spend at least 12 hours on TR II without using a walkthrough, so it's a great buy for its price.Just for reference, here’s how I would rate Tomb Raider 2 relative to the other classic Tomb Raider games I have played, from best to worst:Tomb Raider 1Tomb Raider 3 ( Read my review )Tomb Raider: AnniversaryTomb Raider: LegendTomb Raider 2 Tomb Raider 5 ( Read my review )Tomb Raider: UnderworldTomb Raider 4(I haven’t played Angel of Darkness)

												This game is a classic. It was one of the games that helped spawn the mighty fandom of the Tomb Raider franchise. It's graphics were likely pretty good for the time, but I only played it a few years later, and I still loved it. The water is particularly impressive considering it was released in 1997. However, I can't recommend buying this. The reason why is that it appears they did nothing, or next to nothing, to make it more capable of running on modern machines. I didn't even know it was supposed to appear, so I just clicked return, and the game loaded up, with most of the right side black, and part of the left side cut off. I checked for settings, to no avail. Like a few extremely old games, the video setup is separate from the game (and not exactly intuitive to access from within Steam). Opening it, I wasn't able to change the full screen resolution from 640x480 for some reason. After disabling my second monitor, and setting my main monitor to 800x600 (the smallest resolution where I could still see the apply button), I managed to get the game to appear correctly. A bit of a hassle to say the least. I also installed the widescreen patch. After restarting to re-enable my second monitor, I then tried it in windowed mode. Steam absolutely will not launch it in windowed mode. I had to open it from the exe. It was a travesty. It kept switching the resolution to 640x480 despite being in windowed mode, and was impossible to play. But, somehow, after that, I restarted, and tried it again from steam, and it magically just worked, in full screen mode, without disabling my second monitor. It was still in 640x480 unfortunately, but there was no black bar on one side, and it appeared correctly. I played it for a few minutes before my computer switched to another application on it's own, because the standard keys are set for alt to be the jump key.So, I will play through this game once more, and keep it on my Steam to occasionally play, but I really don't suggest anyone else buys it. They didn't do a thing to try to remove any bugs or anything from what I can tell. They simply took the old retail version and packaged it for steam. Frankly, I would be embarrassed if I worked for them. They should either hand the code to some of their team to squash some bugs occasionally, and clean up the code, or open source it, so maybe someone out there somewhere will choose to clean up the code for them. This game is barely playable on a modern machine. I'm likely gonna have to set up a virtual machine just to play this and a few other old games giving me trouble.

Posted: December 12, 2014
												Tomb Raider II, released in 1997 is certainly a fascinating one. Following on from Lara's adventures in Tomb Raider, Lara finds herself in pursuit of a mythical Chinese artifact, The Dagger of Xian. Lara's journey begins at the Great Wall in China, then to the city of Venice, deep under the sea to the wreckage of the ship, Maria Doria, then to TIbet and finally back to China to face off against the leader of the Fiamma Nera, Marco Bartolli.Gameplay is considerably like the first game, only Lara can now climb ladders, twist around in mid-air or underwater to face the other way, use flares to light up dark areas and carries a much bigger arsenal with weapons like the Grenade Launcher, Harpoon Gun and Automatic Pistols, whilst still maintaining weapons from the first, like the Shotgun and Uzis. Lara controls much better in this game, runs faster than in TR1, Lara also has a new voice actress replacing Shelley Blond, the more mature and rich voice of Judith Gibbins. Another thing to be noted is that Lara has several costume changes in-game, you start in the classic gear, later she changes to a wetsuit for the underwater levels, and finally dons a bomber jacket for the cold Tibetan Foothills before returning to the classic look for the final levels. Nathan McCree returns from the first game to compose the music, and it is chilling! The title theme is a very memorable one, but some of the music can really chill, even scare you!This game is by no means short. It can be quite complicated, but with a good look around and a lot of thought, you can beat it! Highly recommend it, very essential game for any fan of Tomb Raider, good luck!

Posted: January 10, 2016
												Picture yourself (back) in 1997. Sega was still in the hardware business, Microsoft hadn’t yet entered it, Bioshock wouldn’t be released for another decade, and outside Japan, PlayStation didn’t even have analog sticks. It was certainly a very different landscape to the industry we know today, but don’t be fooled; the year had its own type of first-class offerings to gamers at the time. In 1997, Tomb Raider II was Blockbuster of the Year. The start of the year had already seen the western release of Final Fantasy VII, but, a thirty-hour-plus JRPG with a mix of 2D and 3D graphics and its hybrid take on turn-based combat, it was a slow burner. With Tomb Raider II, Lara was running, jumping, swimming, shooting, mowing down thugs on a snowmobile, all in 3D, all in real-time. It was a technical achievement unsurpassed in ‘97, and that would go unsurpassed until the following year, with the likes of Metal Gear Solid, Gran Turismo and, of course, Tomb Raider III. If complaints about the early Tomb Raider sequels revolve mainly around them being too similar to the original, they’re probably true - but it’d be unfair to apply them to the first of these sequels. Tomb Raider II may have been Tomb Raider 1 on steroids, but with the original having set down so groundbreaking a formula, it made little sense to depart from it in the immediate follow-up. And while the core gameplay remains largely the same, Tomb Raider II does bring many new things to the table. From the introduction of vehicles that offer new dimensions in speed and mobility, to a bigger weapon arsenal of which no two are alike, Tomb Raider II is far more than a simple reskin. Even the graphical overhaul breathes new life into the game world, from little touches such as Lara’s full-length ponytail, to sharper textures and the inclusion of sky (a big deal in ‘97!). The result is a succession of characters and environments more rich and with more personality than ever before. The settings and level design for these environments is also a step up from that of the original. With the exception of roughly a third of the game, Tomb Raider II trades the original’s ancient caves and catacombs in favour of the modern and the urban - Lara guns her way through an opera house in Venice, an oil rig, a capsized ship at the bottom of the sea. With these comes the same traps found in the original Tomb Raider, updated to fit within their modern worlds, and admittedly with a hint of the ridiculous - crates swinging with constant momentum and sandbags that fall at exactly the wrong moment, for instance. But suspend your disbelief and you can appreciate inventiveness in the name of maintaining a challenge. The combat, too, has taken a bounding leap from the original’s simple point-and-shoot gunplay. With urban areas comes an army of human foes, each one armed with vicious weaponry, from basic lead pipes and pistols, to pump-action shotguns and flamethrowers, the last of these a one-hit kill if Lara isn’t careful. Now more than ever the combat is a ballet of gunplay and movement, where a split-second decision between offensive and defensive (and the best choice of weapon for each foe) can mean the difference between life and death. Underwater combat also makes its debut, adding a new breed of suspense as well as thrills. Tomb Raider II remains the best-selling game in the series, and it’s a distinction that was well-earned. With the title, developers Core Design took their already-iconic adventurer to new heights, and while the story is predictably hit-or-miss, the production values are sky-high. Almost two decades after its initial release, the game remains a shining example of the action-adventure video game. Outstanding stuff.

												Tomb Raider has always been one of my favourite game series'. I first joined the series when I was five or so and AoD had just been released. Despite that game being considered a low point in the series I loved it. To me there was something about Lara, something about her adventures and the history mixed with mythology that made them unique. Tomb Raider II was, and still is I might add, considered a high point for the series. Not only due to the commercial success it experienced almost twenty years ago but because of everything about it. The game was in 3d which at the time was not really a thing, save for Mario 64, and not only that but it feautured an awesome protagonist, an awesome story and very good graphics for the time. Sure it may not hold up today but it is definitely a game worth revisiting for long time fans of the series or a game worth discovering for people who were drawn in due to the 2013 reboot of the series. The plot follows Lara one year after the first game as she seacrhes for an ancient Chinese dagger said to possess the powers of a dragon to whomever plunges it into their chest. This search takes her all over the world, from China to Venice and beyond. Along the way you will experience fun, and sometimes challenging, platforming, fight all sorts of enemies from feeble spiders to mythalogical monsters. If you don't want to follow the main story right away or you maybe want a refresher course in the controls you can always visit Laras home: Croft Manor. It features an assault course, a hedge maze, various rooms and you can lock her butler Winston in the fridge so, you know, the usual for the classic tomb raider games. Whether you are new to the series or are revisiting it, this is definitely a game worth buying and really what do you have to lose? It's very cheap on steam and virtually everywhere else. However, I must say that it does take a while to get back into the controls which are a little clucky by modern standards but once you do it fits like an old glove.

												[played w/ widescreen mod, border fix, and donglefied Dualshock 2 remapped w/ Xpadder]Classic Tomb Raider games have pretty much disappeared from the collective consciousness and it's a damn shame, because more games started here than just Uncharted. Contrary to popular belief, Tomb Raider 2 aged like fine wine.From the perspective of level design philosophy, this is straight up Dark Souls. Locales vary greatly, rooms and corridors intertwine, and dread is trying to overcome you every step of the way. Even though every environment is blocky, the blocks are layered and textured in such a way that every level feels like an environment first, and a video game level second.People will say that controls in classic TR games are clunky, but they are actually the antithesis of clunky. They are precise and deliberate, is what they are. Somewhat obtuse and with a learning curve, but not clunky. If you endure, you will be flipping, jump-rolling and running jump grabbing without a second thought.Enjoy the fact that the controls are easy to map to a controller, and that the PC version of the game allows you to savestate, because most things in this game are lethal. But it really makes you soak it all in, much like Dark Souls does. Sometimes, you just have to slowly walk to the edge of a platform to make a jump. And the jump is missable. You literally earn every jump you make. Nothing ever railroads you or rushes you forward. I have played TR2 immediately after finishing Uncharted 2 for the first time, and there is just no comparison. TR may have inspired Uncharted's design, but there is really next to nothing left of it anymore.I don't understand how they managed to make a 3D game this good back in 1997.

												Great game.It is more diverse than TR1 for better and worse, some might not like the departure from the buried tombs\ruins style of TR1 to less atmospheric and more urban settings like in Venice or on a (admittedly rather ugly) oil platform. I'm trapped in a scrapheap of rusty metal which sunk 40 fathoms below sea level! (I don't even understand how mutch that is but I guess that must be very very deep since I can't see any sunlight from here.) The water is leaking inside and there are sharks all around me! How the hell am I supposed to get out of here alive?" or "Oh no! Those baddies on machinegunned snowmobiles are shooting me to death and I can't do anything about it!". Obviously it's my favorite amongst the first six Tomb Raider games.What a badass woman! A female equivalent of Chuck Norris!However the game can be so mutch better if somebody sits down and makes a couple of changes to the engine (or releases the engine as open source like idSoftware does it with its games).1. The stretching for aspect ratios other than 4:3 needs to be fixed. It makes the main character look like Gabe Newell on new widescreen monitors.2. The processing power of GPUs increased by several orders of magnitude in comparison to 1997. Who needs distant objects to be turned black and/or thrown out completely in order to save computational complexity nowdays?3. Z-Buffer is buggy. By turning it on and off you just select between different types of glitches. With it there is Z-fighting. Without it some objects further away appear in front of objects that are closer. Both was forgivable back in 1997, but not in 2016.4. I reccomend playing this game with bilinear filtering disbled. Back then textures were VERY low-res and more like something we call pixel art nowdays. Bilinear filtering is a good idea for the new games with highres-textures, but in Tomb Raider 2 it messes up that nice pixel art by making it look smooth and ugly. Like smeared out oil paintings.

												Overall score: 6/10: Old Tomb Raider game with too much emphasis on combat.  There are other better Tomb Raider games from this era to play.  Probably worth it when on sale, but that's about it.I may not be an expert tomb raider, but I have played through this one, number 3, and am currently part way through 4, so I have a decent idea of how the games work.  The reason I have not played the 1st one (officially) is that I decided to get the strory aspect from the newer Tomb Raider: Anniversary, which is the remake.  Given the discrepancy in game release dates and control schemes, it would be vastly unfair to compare it with the older games.Firstly, the graphics have aged.  But then again, the game is released back in 1996, so I can let it pass, it was probably fine, maybe even mind blowing back then.The controls and general gameplay are going to be the hardest to get a handle on when first starting.  In short, Lara controls almost exatcly like a tank.  Do not go in expecting to use a mouse and keyboard with the WSAD mentality, the game uses either ye olde joystick are keyboard only, and I'm not even 100% sure on the joystick.  However, it feels like part of the challenge and fun of the game comes from mastering the controls.Level design is adequate.  I remember it was interesting to navigate and solve the environment puzzles, but I don't remember vast portions of the game, so nothing really left much of an impression.Combat is bad.  The way Lara is controlled does not make combat easy in the first place.  This is complicated, especially in this game, when most of the enemies are in tight quarters, and many are armed with guns.  It makes it difficult to get through the game without guzzling many of the medkits you find.  Fortunately, many of the other games so far have far fewer armed enemies, which balances combat for the better.  I don't remember there being many bosses, it may only be restricted to one, but I'm finding that these Tomb Raider games have a habit of making boss fights rather difficult.Story: I can't remember, so I'm not going to comment too much.  However, these games are rather short on dialogue, character development, narrative.  Mostly, just excuses to move you from location to location and get you into a level.  I'm fine with that, just don't go in expecting a novel masterpiece.Finally, I couldn't get any of the graphical issues or FMV sequences corrected.  I didn't spend much time on it, but this one has more technical issues than the other games I've loaded so far.

Few tips, please read them all before start an old Tomb Raider game:* There are two types of jump. One is "short-distance jump" which can be achieved with Jump key + forward (up arrow), second one is "long-distance jump", you have to gain some velocity to achieve this jump. Run for a while with forward key, then press jump button. Tapping jump button while running is recommended.* Save constantly, ofc if you're sure that you're on a right spot. Especially useful before risky jumps. Even if you don't die, climbing a place again will be a waste of time and boring.* Use a gamepad. Better than keyboard.* Time by time, use walking to set optimal standing point before jumps. While walking, Lara won't fall off from edges (as i observed).Pros and cons:+ Fun "playground"s+ Nostalgic- Controls are horrible, even with a gamepad. Mostly you have to make millimetric calculations to jump properly.- Graphics are deceiving, i mean time by time, you can't understand what is a ladder or movable crate. Actually it's OK for 1997 and for TR2, but even Chronicles (TR5) has that kind of stupidity... Anyway, that was off-topic.- Some of puzzles are bad with a foolish logic. There are a lot of them.- "Playgrounds". That means there is a place you have to solve how to reach the end of a level, but if you take a look, some of places are ridiculous. It doesn't have to be realistic and actually great, since it makes you feel like you're playing a game. But some areas are crazy and with a combination of weird logic of the game, solving those foolish puzzles getting unnecessarily harder (i.e. Opera House level).- Ridiculous death trapsSummaryIf you're a current/next generation gamer, keep away from this title. Even if you like old games and/or grew up with these, consider about it before start to play Tomb Raider 2.

												Overall, a decent game.  Technically, this game holds up quite well, despite being almost 20 years old.  There are some technical issues that the game can have, especially on 64-bit versions of Windows, but I've noticed that Compatibility Mode (run in Windows 95 mode on Windows 7 x64 Pro) tends to take care of most of the issues I've experienced with it.  You'll also want to create a custom resolution in your video card for your native resolution's 4:3 aspect ratio.  So with 1920x1080 as an example, you would create a 1440x1080 resolution to run in full screen, or run in windowed mode to see the game in its proper aspect ratio.As for the game itself, it's not bad.  I think the biggest downfall to the game is that the developer went for the "more is more" approach, and it ended up backfiring on them.  Instead of fixing some of the core game mechanics, Eidos just pushed for a bigger tomb raider game.  We get more weapons, more bad guys, larger levels, more challenging puzzles, and more moves for Lara to execute.  But on the negative, Lara still controls awkwardly, combat is still horrible, and the locations are just straight-up boring.  How can I put this... Tomb Raider II doesn't really have tombs in it.  Oh sure, there's the first level, and the few near the end.  But for the most part, Lara is running around places like the canals of Venice (huh?), opera houses, naval bases, and shipwrecks.  And what's worse, is that the game actually starts out pretty good!  The first level has you romping through a section of the ancient Great Wall of China, and its fantastic.  It's full of booby traps, and generally keeps you on your toes.  The immediately after that, you're thrust into Venice, where you must run around the canals in search of the main bad-guy's hideout...  Weird.  In the end, Tomb Raider II just feels like a tedious and boring version of the original.  While Eidos did make a few touch-up improvements (more polys for Lara, the ability to walk in water, real-time lighting, etc.), they neglected to fix any of the core gameplay issues.  In all fairness, the original Tomb Raider was released in 1996, and this sequel was released just a year later.  So I'm pretty sure that it was a lack of time that prevented Eidos from fixing these issues.  Also, I believe that the third Tomb Raider also came out a year after this, and it also continues the trend of "more" - again, without any fixes to the same gameplay issues that the first game had.If you're a nostalgic fan, go ahead and get this game on sale.  It's not as tedious as the third installment, and if you've already beaten this game, there's no reason you can't romp through it again.  If you've never played the Tomb Raider games, I would strongly advise to start with the first and probably end with the first.  It just goes downhill from there until Crystal Dynamics revived the series with Tomb Raider Legend.TL:DR - Not a bad game at all.  But if you've never played the series, go ahead and start with the first one.  If you have played the first one, just know that the little improvements they made to the game don't outweigh its bigger flaws.  Still recommended though.

												Tomb Raider 2 - ReviewTomb Raider 2 continues the adventures of Lara Croft. One year after Tomb Raider took over the world, the team at Core design return with what is considered by many, myself included as the very best Tomb Raider game in the original series. The story of Tomb Raider II surrounds the mythical 'Dagger of Xian', a weapon which was used by an Emperor of China to command his army. By plunging the weapon into its owner's heart, the weapon has the power to turn its bearer into a dragon. The last battle fought with the Dagger ended when the warrior monks of Tibet removed the knife from the Emperor's heart, whereupon the Emperor died. The Dagger was then returned to its resting place within the Great Wall of China. This will take Lara all over the world and she will battle a dangerous cult intent on getting their hands on the dagger.  As before this is told through FMV cut scenes and in game clips, these are an improvement on before and there is more voice acting than in the previous game which helps improve the story telling experience. As before however it’s not always easy to tell what’s going on but you always have a rough idea and it keeps the game moving well.I personally preferred the story in Tomb Raider 2 to the first game and it takes Lara from the Great Wall of China to Venice then onto an underwater shipwreck, then to the mountains of Nepal and back to China. The level design is fantastic here and all the levels feel unique. One of my complaints about the first game is that many levels felt similar in design, but in Tomb Raider 2 this is not the case, they all stand out with tough, puzzles, great exploration and improved combat. Special mention must go to the Barkhang Monastery level that sees Lara explore an ancient monastery that’s full of great puzzles, many enemies and monks that if left un harmed, aid Lara against the cult members. In 1997 this was very impressive and it made the level stand out in gaming let alone Tomb Raider 2 with the impressive number of people on screen and AI.Graphically Tomb Raider 2 is much improved over the original. Lara’s model has been improved with a higher polygon count, her famous ponytail also makes its first appearance here and reacts impressively to the way Lara moves, running over her shoulder and reacting to wind ect. Environments also look improved with more varied textures, Lara will find herself in more modern surroundings such as Venice and an oil rig rather than just ancient tombs. Dynamic lighting has also been added, Lara’s weapons will cause light to bounce off the environment as she fires them and she now has flares to help brighten up darker areas. Game play has been greatly improved this time around, from the moment I picked up Tomb Raider 2 Lara felt more responsive and allot less “tank” like. It makes it much easier to play Tomb Raider 2 in 2017 than say Tomb Raider 1. Combat has been improved with more guns added to Lara’s arsenal, a grenade launcher, M16 assault rifle and harpoon for underwater combat have been added alongside the classic duel pistols, uzi’s and shotgun. The amount of gun fights in the game has been increased with Lara fighting many more human enemies this time around, the AI is rather standard for 1997 and at times can be relentless in their pursuit of Lara. The combat to exploration balance in Tomb Raider 2 feels perfect and adds a new dimension to the game play. The save system has also been changed, dropping the save crystal’s from the first game for a save anywhere system that makes the game far more forgiving than before, no longer will you have to play through the same sections of the game over and over again when you die.Tomb Raider 2 is an impressive achievement, in one year Core Design has managed to improve on the original in almost every way and create an all time classic. Not only is it one of the best games in the original Tomb Raider series, it’s one of the best games on the original PlayStation. If you’re a fan of Tomb Raider, Lara Croft or action adventure games, it’s a must play!9.6/10 – PC     9.4/10 – PS1

Tomb Raider II was a solid step forward for the early days of the Tomb Raider franchise, which was still in it's infancy back in 1997. In many ways it's a refinement of the first game, carrying on with the same jumping and switch-throwing basics, but dressing them up in more varied environments. The somewhat monotonous rocks and sand of the original are swapped out for interesting locales like an opera house and sunken ship, and in a small but important change, most stages feature an outdoor portion under a blue sky.Lara herself has been given a big upgrade, with a brand new character model that better matches her promotional art. She finally gets to wear her iconic braid in-game, and her chest no longer looks like it could take your eye out. This game is also the start of costume changes for Lara, kicking off the tradition with a particularly famous wetsuit.Lara's action repertoire is expanded with two new moves. She can climb ladders now, which feels like a natural addition to her moveset, and integrates just as smoothly into the game's level designs. The new flares that she carries are less successful. Though necessary on a few occasions, it's questionable whether they earn having their own dedicated button – but at least they produce a nice lighting effect.On the downside, even in its second outing there are signs that classic Tomb Raider is showing its age. Its new environments are assembled from the same clumsy building blocks of the first game, resulting in some weird proportions in places like the interiors of Lara's home. More egregiously, the majority of the enemies Lara faces this time are human, but with no difference in AI from the animal enemies she fought the first time around. Equipped with guns, the new human foes are a lot more dangerous, but your best tactic is still to find a high ledge where you can shoot repeatedly at them, as they stupidly run around in confused circles below. Eventually these encounters feel like tiresome interruptions of the core gameplay.Of course it's no surprise that Tomb Raider II is at its best when it's not focused on combat, and the series' particular brand of puzzle platforming is still excellent when it's left alone to do its thing. Some standout stages are the monastery (which is formed as a central hub surrounded by short platforming challenges) and the temple (a thorough gauntlet that will test all the skills you've accumulated).With it's second game, the Tomb Raider series was hurriedly growing into the fame that it had fallen into unexpectedly. Some of its improvements were essential to defining the character of the franchise's early years, and most of what was fun about the first game carries over intact. But at the same time, it's clear that the original formula is already being stretched toward its limit – and the series' ongoing struggle to balance action with adventure was a problem right from the first sequel.

												Tomb Raider II brings back the iconic charismatic archaeologist, Lara Croft, on another epic journey around the globe to investigate the legend around the Dagger of Xian. Her second adventure takes her along the Great Wall of China, the snowy terrains of Tibet, Italy’s city of Venice and a sunken shipwreck, accompanied by more complex series of jumping puzzles and death traps, lever activated time puzzles and the merciless killing of treasure hunting goons and exotic animals that stand in her path.The game grants Lara the ability to climb ladders and craggy walls, to roll in the air and underwater for trickier puzzles, and to drive vehicles such as speedboats and snowmobiles around certain levels in the game, which can be incredibly fun and very tedious at the same time. Flares have been thrown into the game to allow Lara to explore particularly dark areas with ease, which come in handy for some of the later levels, along with new weapons packing serious firepower like the M16 assault rifle, a grenade launcher and automatic dual pistols (which replace the dual magnums that were available in TR1), along with all weapons within the previous game.Enemies now have the intelligence to climb surfaces in order to reach Lara and carry pretty damaging weaponry, making combat somewhat more difficult, especially when they corner the player in tight spaces. Meaning there will be more ammo to find, a few more medicine packs to collect, and there are 3 secrets to find throughout each level; the gold, jade and silver dragons.For those who have played Tomb Raider I, you will be pleased to hear that instead of having to save your progress at a save crystal and having to restart tedious levels every time Lara plummets to her death from that point, Tomb Raider II allows you to save your progress from your save manual whenever and wherever. It makes life much, much easier.All environments and graphics appear to have been enhanced both in colour and in quality in this game, ultimately keeping movable blocks and secret areas better hidden, so it’s very easy to overlook a potential secret or an area full of loot if you aren’t actively exploring the entire level. The soundtrack in the game has been heavily built off its predecessor, only playing on certain cues like when the protagonist steps into the path of a rolling boulder, as it did in the previous game.Another change to be noted is the change in voice actress for our fearless protagonist. Personally, I felt that her new voice fitted Lara better as she sounds much more experienced and capable of handling herself like a badass, whereas, her voice in TR1 portrayed her to be more of an arrogant adolescent.The tutorial area in Lara Croft’s manor has developed greatly from its elder. The crates blocking most of the large manor have now been removed, inviting the player to explore the charming home more thoroughly. The gymnasium and the swimming pool reappear in this game, but with much obstacles to manoeuvre through and a prettier pool to swim around in.Here is where you are introduced to Winston, Lara’s old butler who is intent on following her around the house while groaning and carrying a tray of rattling tea cups. On the odd occasion when I accidently ran into him, there is a chance that he will break wind. It can be pretty fun for a while, but eventually having him dog you around the manor will grow tedious. My solution was to have him follow me to the meat locker in the kitchen, wait for him to follow a certain distance behind, then perform a well-timed leap out of the area, and lock him in. I found watching him try to walk through the door grunting and groaning to be quite amusing. Cruel, but amusing.Lara can now venture outside the manor and explore the maze behind it. The main section behind the maze is an assault course the player can now test out their skills on obstacles that are a bit more challenging than the gym.All in all, if you’re looking for a game where you can relax and enjoy shooting lead into your enemies, but still challenging enough that it keeps you wondering about any potential death traps around the corner, Tomb Raider II is a classic game with plenty of everything and is generally fun to play, even when using the Playstation controls, although the PC controls are much more fluid.

												NOTE:  I had to use a third party piece of software to be able to be able to map an XBox 360 pad in a sensible configuration.  I'd give this game a 7/10 score though because although it has many timeless elements of game design that still make it quite a bit of fun to play through, it does not have as clear and interesting a story as the first Tomb Raider, it falls short of that mark on most measures; and additionally it shows it's age graphically.  Is it still worth playing, yeah, but it could play much better with a bit of modernization.  The character model for Lara is of course excellently done for the time, as are her animations; but I think there may be more polygons in her model than in the rest of the game.  The modelling though isn't really where the game suffers;but rather in the low resolution textures.  The cut-scenes look extremely grainy on modern resolutions and the textures on the environments are sometimes poor enough to really pull you out of any immersion you may have.  I will say that there are a very wide variety of environments and some of them are quite in interesting, although if you're like me, you may not be able to clearly understand why you are actually going to all these peculiar places.  The story just isn't particularly clear or engaging.  The platforming controls are somewhat finicky.  You really end up using a set of manuevers in kind of the same way you might in a fighting game to clear these challenges.  Once you get those moves down, it's usually more a matter of finding where you need to platform to rather than the execution that is the challenge.  There are some block pushing/lever pulling puzzles as well and these are solid, usually not too much of a challenge but that's fine as they don't overstay their welcome.  As far as the combat, it's very similar to the first Tomb Raider as well, and the added weapon, and enemy variety is one of the real clear improvements over it's predecessor.  Overall, the game is dated, but fun.  If you are considering taking a look at the classic roots of the franchise though, I'd start with Tomb Raider 1 (better story, somewhat better level design, and native x-input support for the PC), and if you enjoy that .. heck yeah TR 2 is worth the time investment.

												Tomb Raider 2 - ReviewTomb Raider 2 continues the adventures of Lara Croft. One year after Tomb Raider took over the world, the team at Core design return with what is considered by many, myself included as the very best Tomb Raider game in the original series. The story of Tomb Raider II surrounds the mythical 'Dagger of Xian', a weapon which was used by an Emperor of China to command his army. By plunging the weapon into its owner's heart, the weapon has the power to turn its bearer into a dragon. The last battle fought with the Dagger ended when the warrior monks of Tibet removed the knife from the Emperor's heart, whereupon the Emperor died. The Dagger was then returned to its resting place within the Great Wall of China. This will take Lara all over the world and she will battle a dangerous cult intent on getting their hands on the dagger.  As before this is told through FMV cut scenes and in game clips, these are an improvement on before and there is more voice acting than in the previous game which helps improve the story telling experience. As before however it’s not always easy to tell what’s going on but you always have a rough idea and it keeps the game moving well.I personally preferred the story in Tomb Raider 2 to the first game and it takes Lara from the Great Wall of China to Venice then onto an underwater shipwreck, then to the mountains of Nepal and back to China. The level design is fantastic here and all the levels feel unique. One of my complaints about the first game is that many levels felt similar in design, but in Tomb Raider 2 this is not the case, they all stand out with tough, puzzles, great exploration and improved combat. Special mention must go to the Barkhang Monastery level that sees Lara explore an ancient monastery that’s full of great puzzles, many enemies and monks that if left un harmed, aid Lara against the cult members. In 1997 this was very impressive and it made the level stand out in gaming let alone Tomb Raider 2 with the impressive number of people on screen and AI.Graphically Tomb Raider 2 is much improved over the original. Lara’s model has been improved with a higher polygon count, her famous ponytail also makes its first appearance here and reacts impressively to the way Lara moves, running over her shoulder and reacting to wind ect. Environments also look improved with more varied textures, Lara will find herself in more modern surroundings such as Venice and an oil rig rather than just ancient tombs. Dynamic lighting has also been added, Lara’s weapons will cause light to bounce off the environment as she fires them and she now has flares to help brighten up darker areas. Game play has been greatly improved this time around, from the moment I picked up Tomb Raider 2 Lara felt more responsive and allot less “tank” like. It makes it much easier to play Tomb Raider 2 in 2017 than say Tomb Raider 1. Combat has been improved with more guns added to Lara’s arsenal, a grenade launcher, M16 assault rifle and harpoon for underwater combat have been added alongside the classic duel pistols, uzi’s and shotgun. The amount of gun fights in the game has been increased with Lara fighting many more human enemies this time around, the AI is rather standard for 1997 and at times can be relentless in their pursuit of Lara. The combat to exploration balance in Tomb Raider 2 feels perfect and adds a new dimension to the game play. The save system has also been changed, dropping the save crystal’s from the first game for a save anywhere system that makes the game far more forgiving than before, no longer will you have to play through the same sections of the game over and over again when you die.Tomb Raider 2 is an impressive achievement, in one year Core Design has managed to improve on the original in almost every way and create an all time classic. Not only is it one of the best games in the original Tomb Raider series, it’s one of the best games on the original PlayStation. If you’re a fan of Tomb Raider, Lara Croft or action adventure games, it’s a must play!9.6/10 – PC     9.4/10 – PS1

Tomb Raider II was a solid step forward for the early days of the Tomb Raider franchise, which was still in it's infancy back in 1997. In many ways it's a refinement of the first game, carrying on with the same jumping and switch-throwing basics, but dressing them up in more varied environments. The somewhat monotonous rocks and sand of the original are swapped out for interesting locales like an opera house and sunken ship, and in a small but important change, most stages feature an outdoor portion under a blue sky.Lara herself has been given a big upgrade, with a brand new character model that better matches her promotional art. She finally gets to wear her iconic braid in-game, and her chest no longer looks like it could take your eye out. This game is also the start of costume changes for Lara, kicking off the tradition with a particularly famous wetsuit.Lara's action repertoire is expanded with two new moves. She can climb ladders now, which feels like a natural addition to her moveset, and integrates just as smoothly into the game's level designs. The new flares that she carries are less successful. Though necessary on a few occasions, it's questionable whether they earn having their own dedicated button – but at least they produce a nice lighting effect.On the downside, even in its second outing there are signs that classic Tomb Raider is showing its age. Its new environments are assembled from the same clumsy building blocks of the first game, resulting in some weird proportions in places like the interiors of Lara's home. More egregiously, the majority of the enemies Lara faces this time are human, but with no difference in AI from the animal enemies she fought the first time around. Equipped with guns, the new human foes are a lot more dangerous, but your best tactic is still to find a high ledge where you can shoot repeatedly at them, as they stupidly run around in confused circles below. Eventually these encounters feel like tiresome interruptions of the core gameplay.Of course it's no surprise that Tomb Raider II is at its best when it's not focused on combat, and the series' particular brand of puzzle platforming is still excellent when it's left alone to do its thing. Some standout stages are the monastery (which is formed as a central hub surrounded by short platforming challenges) and the temple (a thorough gauntlet that will test all the skills you've accumulated).With it's second game, the Tomb Raider series was hurriedly growing into the fame that it had fallen into unexpectedly. Some of its improvements were essential to defining the character of the franchise's early years, and most of what was fun about the first game carries over intact. But at the same time, it's clear that the original formula is already being stretched toward its limit – and the series' ongoing struggle to balance action with adventure was a problem right from the first sequel.

												After 37 long and amazing hours I finally managed to finish this game. It was a great experience and an even better game than its prequel. I really like the direction in which this game took the Tomb Raider Series after Tomb Raider I. Still there are some flaws I could not ignore. The story is somewhat weird and not quite as interesting as Lara's first adventure. In addition to that it has a fair amount of flawed logic. Still this game is a big improvement. The first half of the game simply amazed me. The locations and non linear leveldesign were absolutely astonishing while the huge amount of fights made up for a fast paced experience. I loved solving the jump puzzles and found myself (positively) confused by the vast amount of options in each level. However, the second half of the game felt a bit over the top. It took me into the more supernatural part of the story, which for instance was really cool, but (in my humble opinion) felt like it was stretched over too many levels. I also think the fighting mechanics still offer great space for improvement so I am very curious to play the next Tomb Raider titles.No matter its flaws this game is still very worth playing especially for people who enjoy Tomb Raider games or Tomb Raider like games. That being said I encourage everyone to play this amazing piece of gaming history.
